qas.question: What is an example of a corporate sponsor of a basketball team?
What is an example of a team of former college players?
When did the FIBA stop allowing pros on foreign national teams?
When did the NCAA decide college teams could only play other college teams?
How often does the NCAA allow college teams to go overseas?

answers.text: one foreign tour every four years

qas.question: How did minor college basketball teams begin their season?
What kind of teams were made up of college players?

plausible_answers.text: professional players on foreign national teams

qas.question: Who allowed games between non-college teams in 2003?
Where do minor basketball teams still travel to.

context: Traditionally, major college basketball teams began their seasons <b5_0>with a few exhibition games<b5_0/>. They played <b6_0>travelling teams<b6_0/> made up of former college players on teams such as <a1_0>Athletes in Action<a1_0/> or a team sponsored by <a0_0>Marathon Oil<a0_0/>. On occasion before <a2_0>1992<a2_0/>, when FIBA allowed <b7_0>professional players on foreign national teams<b7_0/>, colleges played those teams in exhibitions. However, in <a3_0>2003<a3_0/>, the <b8_0>National Collegiate Athletic Association<b8_0/> banned games with non-college teams. Some teams have begun scheduling exhibition games against teams in NCAA Division II and NCAA Division III, or even against colleges and universities located in Canada. Major college basketball teams still travel <b9_0>to other countries<b9_0/> during the summer to play in exhibition games, although a college team is allowed <a4_0>one foreign tour every four years<a4_0/>, and a maximum of ten games in each tour.
